climbs.name: Triple Crown
climbs.fa: Tom Jungst, Pat Callis & Bill Dockins, June 1987

content.description:
The ominous maw to the left of Dark House. Climbs MUCH better than it looks...especially rowdy finish.

Climbing Dark Horse via the right of two lower finger cracks, saves the left of the two as a much better start than the dirty corner described in the Dockins guide
content.protection: Single rack. A great 0.75 BD protects the challenging roof pull.

content.description:
Get yer steep jamming on! Scramble up the

BO Buttress

gully for 20 feet to the start. Follow sustained, but positive overhanging jams and crimps on a right leaning system of cracks to a one bolt anchor. The other bolt was chopped....back it up with a .75?

Walk off.
content.location:
BO Buttress

gully, shares start with

Arachnophobia

.

content.description:
Start out bouldering up and left to gain the positive rail / seam and some thin gear. Traverse left along the rail until possible to clip the bolt and connect up to the next seam. (5.12) From the seam, traverse left to a vertical crack that leads to a 2 bolt anchor.

Done ground up.
content.protection: Thin and offset cams, HBs and a quickdraw.
content.location: On the south face of a small formation inbetween the BO and Blackline, along the old climbers trail.

content.protection: Mixed: 4 bolts with BD cams from 0.3-3, chain anchor.
content.location: Up above the lower two ribs of BO Buttress are two more similar ribs. The rib lookers left has an old trad route on it, maybe more. The rib to the right, almost straight above Dont Sweat the Small Stuff has a new mixed route.

content.description:
This was initially done as a very poorly protected headpoint with only a little cleaning done. I did it in this style as there was a bit of bolting controversy circling the Gally around that time, I wanted to do it in similar style to the neighboring Boveng's Overhang, and I didn't think it merited bolting. However, as such it sat completely ignored for the last 10 years.

In June 2019, it was retro-bolted by a party unaware that it had been climbed as there was little evidence left behind and the sparse/marginal gear options understandably didn't look like reasonable pro. I was contacted by the bolter after they realized their mistake, and am fine with the bolting and cleaning that it apparently received. It seems to me to be a better use of the resource given the growing popularity of the canyon, and the fact that a deadly moderate doesn't really appeal to most folks. It can now serve as a convenient warm-up for lines on B.O. Buttress and the south face of the Waltz.
content.location: The obvious river-facing prow 10' right of the B.O. Buttress proper.

content.description: Prepare to climb over tiny nuts and RPs on this awesome Gally test! Climb/layback up a large flake, then slam in as many good nuts as you can find. Punch it through the crux and follow the great crack to the top. Walk off.
content.protection: A 4 protects the bottom very well. Take a handful of small cams, small wires, and RPs (an offset or two was handy).

content.description: Dark Horse is located on the right side of the north face of the BO Buttress, in between Boveng's and Triple Crown. Climb a crack system, trending left past two roofs. Crux is at the second roof. Continue to the top of the buttress.
content.protection: Standard rack. Gear anchor. Walk off.

content.description:
Good for a new crack/trad leader. A quick, fun romp if The Waltz is busy.

Descent:

Rappel route.
content.protection: Will take lots of BD 1-4 sizes. Other smaller gear here and there. Chain anchors.
content.location: From the base of The Waltz, head lookers right towards BO buttress. Route is in a small alcove facing the river.

content.description: Mostly fingers, up an overhanging wall, with the crux near the top. Walk off.
content.location: This route starts on 'Tarantella', but cuts up and left rather than to the right. At the ledge, finish on the 'Tarantella' corner. The furthest down hill of the 3 cracks in the gully, in between 'Densepack' and 'Tarantella'.

climbs.name: Boveng's Overhang
climbs.fa: Bill Dockins, Peter Boveng, & Dave Batten (July 1982)

content.description:
This very difficult to protect, yet fun route, is worth ticking off at least once. Climb up extremely excellent crystalline pink rock below the large roof. Move towards the roofs left margin, and pull the airy move up onto the face above. Rock quality decreases after the roof.

Descent:

Walk off right.
content.protection:
Minimal and not confidence inspiring. Micro cams and nuts up to BD#1. No fixed anchors. Fantastic crack for the belay about 10' back from the lip.

To build a TR gear anchor, bring a couple of cordalettes, and a few cams from finger to hand sized.
content.location: River facing prow of the most northerly (closest to the Waltz) buttress in the BO area.

climbs.name: Aracnophobia
climbs.fa: P. Kingsbury, A. Fruh, T. Williams   May 2007

content.description: This is the furthest up hill crack in the gully on the B.O. buttress.  Fingers and liebacks, lead to a reach move and then easier terrain up high.  Walk off
content.protection: mostly finger size, and a single set up to old 3.5 camalot
content.location: the most uphill crack of the 3 in the gully.
